context: Because of these analytical challenges in measuring reactive BVOC, there has been only limited success in measuring their fluxes at the canopy scale (Ciccioli et al., 1999). Leaf- and branch-level enclosure experiments provide viable alternatives for obtaining fluxes of reactive and low-volatility compounds when ambient measurements are not possible. Several investigators have measured isoprene emissions at the leaf- and branch-level and have characterized these emissions with respect to leaf development, light environment, canopy position, and temperature history (Harley et al., 1996; Sharkey et al., 1996; Geron et al., 2000; Singsaas and Sharkey, 2000; Pétron et al., 2001). Isotopic labeling experiments using 13C or deuterium have been performed to finely characterize time-dependent isoprene production and emissions (Tholl et al., 2006; and references therein). Branch-level emissions of compounds other than isoprene (e.g. MT, SQT, oxygenated BVOC) are more difficult to quantify because of the reasons previously discussed. Although challenging to obtain, quantitative emission rates of these other BVOC compounds from enclosures can be used to estimate whole-canopy fluxes and their roles in atmospheric processes.
